title: How to Remove Caulk

methods.name: Removing Caulk from Showers, Tubs, and Kitchens

steps.headline: Apply caulk remover and let it sit for at least 2 hours.
steps.description: Commercial caulk remover is the simplest choice and may be your best option for silicone caulk. Apply the caulk remover by squeezing a wide bead along the caulk line, completely covering it from end to end. Let it sit for several hours as directed on the label.Tip: Fresh caulk can usually be removed without softening it beforehand. If you are removing water-based acrylic caulks or polyvinyl acetate resins, soak the caulk by dampening it with isopropyl rubbing alcohol instead of using a caulk remover.

steps.headline: Slice through the caulk with a blade.
steps.description: Use a small razor blade or box cutter to cut the caulk away from the surface it is on. Make sure your cuts separate the caulk from the surface that it is attached to so that it is easier to pull it off later. Use caution when you are cutting so that you don’t nick or mar the surface that the caulk is attached to.

steps.headline: Scrape off the caulk with a putty knife.
steps.description: Use a flat putty knife to gently scrape any visible caulk off of the surface of your tub or tiles. Hold the scraper at a shallow angle, keeping it as flat as possible, to avoid scratching the surface.

steps.headline: Pull caulk out of deep crevices with needle-nose pliers.
steps.description: If you cannot reach some of the caulk with your scraper, use needle-nose pliers to pick and pull out any visible chunks. Needle-nose pliers are preferable to other types of pliers since they tend to be narrower and are easier to maneuver in and out of small crevices.

steps.headline: Clean off any residue with soap and water.
steps.description: You might have small pieces of caulk left over. To remove it, wash the area with soap and warm water until there is no caulk left. Make sure to dispose of all caulk by putting it in the garbage, and avoid rinsing it down the drain, since it could clog your pipes.

steps.headline: Rinse the area with mineral water.
steps.description: Before applying any chemical solvent to wood, rinse the area with mineral water or distilled water to remove any residue. Pat the area dry with a clean cloth or rag. You can buy mineral water at your local grocery store.

steps.headline: Dampen the caulked area with a chemical silicone solvent.
steps.description: Choose a chemical solvent that is made to dissolve silicone caulk. Dampen the stained area with the solvent using a clean rag.Common silicone solvents include: Methylene Chloride, Dichloromethane, Methylene Bichloride, and Methylene Dichloride. Read the safety warnings on your solvent label carefully. If you have sensitive skin, use gloves to protect your hands when you apply the solvent. You only need to use solvents on silicone caulk stains. Other types of caulk stains, like acrylic and non-acrylic caulks, are less stubborn and can usually be removed with nothing but water and physical scraping.

steps.headline: Mix some of the solvent with a white absorbent material, like plaster or flour.
steps.description: Combine additional solvent with enough white absorbent material to form a thick paste. You can use molding plaster, white flour, or even powdered chalk. Note that you'll need about 1 lb (450 g) of paste for every 1 square foot (930 cm).

steps.headline: Apply the paste to the stain with a spatula tool.
steps.description: Layer the paste on the caulk stain using a plastic or wooden spatula. Make sure that the paste is ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) thick or less. This paste should cover the entire stain and extend a bit past the edges. If you do not let the paste extend past the stain, the stain could end up being forced onto clean patches of stone. After applying the paste, make sure that the coating is free of any air pockets.

steps.headline: Let the paste sit for 48 hours.
steps.description: You can cover the paste with a plastic sheet and masking tape if you are worried it will get bumped or have contaminants dropped in it. Let it sit for 48 hours undisturbed.

steps.headline: Dampen the area with the paste with mineral water.
steps.description: This will soften the hardened paste enough to help lift it off and cleans the area of any dirt or debris it has picked up. Use a clean rag to blot the mineral water onto the area.

steps.headline: Scrape the dried paste and caulk off with a reefing hook or putty knife.
steps.description: If the caulk is in a seam, use a reefing hook to pull it out of the crevices in the wood. Use a putty knife to gently scrape away the paste and the loosened caulk if it is sitting on top of the wood. Use caution when you scrape, since wood is soft and can be nicked easily by sharp tools. You can purchase these tools at most home improvement stores.

steps.headline: Rinse the area with mineral water.
steps.description: Rinse the area once more with mineral water or distilled water to remove any residue of paste or caulk. Blot dry with clean paper towels or rags. You might need to apply this treatment multiple times before all the caulk comes up. You can do so once the surface is completely dry.

text: Removing Caulk from Showers, Tubs, and Kitchens Apply caulk remover and let it sit for at least 2 hours. Commercial caulk remover is the simplest choice and may be your best option for silicone caulk. Apply the caulk remover by squeezing a wide bead along the caulk line, completely covering it from end to end. Let it sit for several hours as directed on the label.Tip: Fresh caulk can usually be removed without softening it beforehand. If you are removing water-based acrylic caulks or polyvinyl acetate resins, soak the caulk by dampening it with isopropyl rubbing alcohol instead of using a caulk remover. Slice through the caulk with a blade. Use a small razor blade or box cutter to cut the caulk away from the surface it is on. Make sure your cuts separate the caulk from the surface that it is attached to so that it is easier to pull it off later. Use caution when you are cutting so that you don’t nick or mar the surface that the caulk is attached to. Scrape off the caulk with a putty knife. Use a flat putty knife to gently scrape any visible caulk off of the surface of your tub or tiles. Hold the scraper at a shallow angle, keeping it as flat as possible, to avoid scratching the surface. Pull caulk out of deep crevices with needle-nose pliers. If you cannot reach some of the caulk with your scraper, use needle-nose pliers to pick and pull out any visible chunks. Needle-nose pliers are preferable to other types of pliers since they tend to be narrower and are easier to maneuver in and out of small crevices. Clean off any residue with soap and water. You might have small pieces of caulk left over. To remove it, wash the area with soap and warm water until there is no caulk left. Make sure to dispose of all caulk by putting it in the garbage, and avoid rinsing it down the drain, since it could clog your pipes. Removing Silicone Caulk from Wood Rinse the area with mineral water. Before applying any chemical solvent to wood, rinse the area with mineral water or distilled water to remove any residue. Pat the area dry with a clean cloth or rag. You can buy mineral water at your local grocery store. Dampen the caulked area with a chemical silicone solvent. Choose a chemical solvent that is made to dissolve silicone caulk. Dampen the stained area with the solvent using a clean rag.Common silicone solvents include: Methylene Chloride, Dichloromethane, Methylene Bichloride, and Methylene Dichloride. Read the safety warnings on your solvent label carefully. If you have sensitive skin, use gloves to protect your hands when you apply the solvent. You only need to use solvents on silicone caulk stains. Other types of caulk stains, like acrylic and non-acrylic caulks, are less stubborn and can usually be removed with nothing but water and physical scraping. Mix some of the solvent with a white absorbent material, like plaster or flour. Combine additional solvent with enough white absorbent material to form a thick paste. You can use molding plaster, white flour, or even powdered chalk. Note that you'll need about 1 lb (450 g) of paste for every 1 square foot (930 cm). Apply the paste to the stain with a spatula tool. Layer the paste on the caulk stain using a plastic or wooden spatula. Make sure that the paste is ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) thick or less. This paste should cover the entire stain and extend a bit past the edges. If you do not let the paste extend past the stain, the stain could end up being forced onto clean patches of stone. After applying the paste, make sure that the coating is free of any air pockets. Let the paste sit for 48 hours. You can cover the paste with a plastic sheet and masking tape if you are worried it will get bumped or have contaminants dropped in it. Let it sit for 48 hours undisturbed. Dampen the area with the paste with mineral water. This will soften the hardened paste enough to help lift it off and cleans the area of any dirt or debris it has picked up. Use a clean rag to blot the mineral water onto the area. Scrape the dried paste and caulk off with a reefing hook or putty knife. If the caulk is in a seam, use a reefing hook to pull it out of the crevices in the wood. Use a putty knife to gently scrape away the paste and the loosened caulk if it is sitting on top of the wood. Use caution when you scrape, since wood is soft and can be nicked easily by sharp tools. You can purchase these tools at most home improvement stores. Rinse the area with mineral water. Rinse the area once more with mineral water or distilled water to remove any residue of paste or caulk. Blot dry with clean paper towels or rags. You might need to apply this treatment multiple times before all the caulk comes up. You can do so once the surface is completely dry.
sentences: Removing Caulk from Showers, Tubs, and Kitchens Apply caulk remover and let it sit for at least 2 hours.
Commercial caulk remover is the simplest choice and may be your best option for silicone caulk.
Apply the caulk remover by squeezing a wide bead along the caulk line, completely covering it from end to end.
Let it sit for several hours as directed on the label.Tip: Fresh caulk can usually be removed without softening it beforehand.
If you are removing water-based acrylic caulks or polyvinyl acetate resins, soak the caulk by dampening it with isopropyl rubbing alcohol instead of using a caulk remover.
Slice through the caulk with a blade.
Use a small razor blade or box cutter to cut the caulk away from the surface it is on.
Make sure your cuts separate the caulk from the surface that it is attached to so that it is easier to pull it off later.
Use caution when you are cutting so that you don’t nick or mar the surface that the caulk is attached to.
Scrape off the caulk with a putty knife.
Use a flat putty knife to gently scrape any visible caulk off of the surface of your tub or tiles.
Hold the scraper at a shallow angle, keeping it as flat as possible, to avoid scratching the surface.
Pull caulk out of deep crevices with needle-nose pliers.
If you cannot reach some of the caulk with your scraper, use needle-nose pliers to pick and pull out any visible chunks.
Needle-nose pliers are preferable to other types of pliers since they tend to be narrower and are easier to maneuver in and out of small crevices.
Clean off any residue with soap and water.
You might have small pieces of caulk left over.
To remove it, wash the area with soap and warm water until there is no caulk left.
Make sure to dispose of all caulk by putting it in the garbage, and avoid rinsing it down the drain, since it could clog your pipes.
Removing Silicone Caulk from Wood Rinse the area with mineral water.
Before applying any chemical solvent to wood, rinse the area with mineral water or distilled water to remove any residue.
Pat the area dry with a clean cloth or rag.
You can buy mineral water at your local grocery store.
Dampen the caulked area with a chemical silicone solvent.
Choose a chemical solvent that is made to dissolve silicone caulk.
Dampen the stained area with the solvent using a clean rag.Common silicone solvents include: Methylene Chloride, Dichloromethane, Methylene Bichloride, and Methylene Dichloride.
Read the safety warnings on your solvent label carefully.
If you have sensitive skin, use gloves to protect your hands when you apply the solvent.
You only need to use solvents on silicone caulk stains.
Other types of caulk stains, like acrylic and non-acrylic caulks, are less stubborn and can usually be removed with nothing but water and physical scraping.
Mix some of the solvent with a white absorbent material, like plaster or flour.
Combine additional solvent with enough white absorbent material to form a thick paste.
You can use molding plaster, white flour, or even powdered chalk.
Note that you'll need about 1 lb (450 g) of paste for every 1 square foot (930 cm).
Apply the paste to the stain with a spatula tool.
Layer the paste on the caulk stain using a plastic or wooden spatula.
Make sure that the paste is ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) thick or less.
This paste should cover the entire stain and extend a bit past the edges.
If you do not let the paste extend past the stain, the stain could end up being forced onto clean patches of stone.
After applying the paste, make sure that the coating is free of any air pockets.
Let the paste sit for 48 hours.
You can cover the paste with a plastic sheet and masking tape if you are worried it will get bumped or have contaminants dropped in it.
Let it sit for 48 hours undisturbed.
Dampen the area with the paste with mineral water.
This will soften the hardened paste enough to help lift it off and cleans the area of any dirt or debris it has picked up.
Use a clean rag to blot the mineral water onto the area.
Scrape the dried paste and caulk off with a reefing hook or putty knife.
If the caulk is in a seam, use a reefing hook to pull it out of the crevices in the wood.
Use a putty knife to gently scrape away the paste and the loosened caulk if it is sitting on top of the wood.
Use caution when you scrape, since wood is soft and can be nicked easily by sharp tools.
You can purchase these tools at most home improvement stores.
Rinse the area with mineral water.
Rinse the area once more with mineral water or distilled water to remove any residue of paste or caulk.
Blot dry with clean paper towels or rags.
You might need to apply this treatment multiple times before all the caulk comes up.
You can do so once the surface is completely dry.
